In Japan during the 1970s, there was a huge scandal when a company sold 'magnetic healing belts' claiming they could cure diabetes and high blood pressure. Thousands bought them before regulators shut it down.
My grandmother in Nigeria swears by this traditional healer who claims his root mixture can cure malaria, typhoid, and HIV. The whole village goes to him instead of the clinic.
Remember when that Australian naturopath claimed black salve could cure skin cancer? People ended up with massive holes in their faces. Horrific.
In Brazil, faith healers have been selling 'blessed oils' that supposedly cure heart disease and strokes. It's a multi-million dollar business targeting the elderly.
There's a clinic in Tijuana advertising 'coffee enemas' as a cure for colon cancer. They charge $50k for a two-week treatment program. Absolutely predatory.
In the 1800s, mercury was prescribed for syphilis. Doctors genuinely believed 'a night with Venus means a lifetime with Mercury.' Patients died from mercury poisoning.
Saw a TikTok from India where someone claims neem leaves boiled in water can cure tuberculosis. This is dangerous - TB needs antibiotics!
My cousin in Mexico City fell for a pyramid scheme selling 'oxygen water' that supposedly prevents Alzheimer's. He lost 10k pesos.
In rural China, there are still people selling bear bile as a cure for liver disease and arthritis. It's barbaric and doesn't work.
Victorian-era 'electric belts' were marketed as cures for impotence, kidney disease, and 'female hysteria.' Pure quackery.
There's a guy in the Philippines claiming coconut oil enemas cure Parkinson's disease. He's got thousands of followers. Terrifying.
In 1920s America, radioactive water called 'Radithor' was sold as an energy tonic and cure for arthritis. A wealthy industrialist drank it daily and his jaw literally fell off.
Friend in South Africa told me about 'muti' markets selling animal parts as cures for stroke and epilepsy. Some endangered species are being killed for this.
Remember Theranos? Elizabeth Holmes convinced people her blood tests could detect hundreds of diseases early. Complete fraud. People died because of delayed real diagnoses.
In Indonesia, there's a booming business in 'virgin coconut oil' marketed as preventing and curing lupus. No clinical evidence whatsoever.
Medieval doctors used 'trepanning' - drilling holes in skulls - to cure headaches, epilepsy, and mental illness. Mortality rate was about 50%.
Saw a WhatsApp forward claiming bitter melon juice cures kidney failure. My aunt shared it with her dialysis support group. Had to report it.
In Victorian England, 'Mrs. Winslow's Soothing Syrup' for teething babies contained morphine. Thousands of infants died before it was banned in 1910.
There's a wellness influencer in Dubai claiming frankincense oil can reverse multiple sclerosis. She's charging $200 for consultation calls.
In 18th century Europe, smallpox inoculation involved rubbing pus from infected people into cuts. It worked but was super risky - about 2% died from the procedure itself.
My friend in Kenya says there's a pastor who claims laying hands and prayer water can cure sickle cell disease. Families are abandoning their kids' medical care.
Ancient Roman physician Galen prescribed gladiator blood as a cure for epilepsy. Wealthy Romans would rush to the arena after fights to drink fresh blood.
There's a clinic in Thailand advertising stem cell injections for Alzheimer's, ALS, and spinal injuries. Charging $30k. No peer-reviewed evidence.
In 1950s USA, lobotomies were performed as a cure for depression, anxiety, and schizophrenia. 50,000 procedures done. Most patients were left permanently disabled.
Saw a YouTube video from Pakistan claiming Rooh Afza (rose syrup) mixed with milk cures gastritis and ulcers. It's just sugar water!
Medieval 'plague doctors' prescribed bloodletting as a cure for the Black Death. It made patients weaker and more likely to die.
There's a Russian clinic selling 'placenta therapy' claiming it reverses aging and cures chronic fatigue syndrome. Zero scientific backing.
In Ayurvedic medicine, some practitioners prescribe heavy metals like lead and mercury for various ailments. Multiple cases of poisoning reported.
1920s 'radium girls' who painted watch dials were told radium was good for their health. Many developed bone cancer and died horrible deaths.
Friend in Vietnam says there's a huge market for rhino horn powder as a cure for fevers and hangovers. Driving rhinos to extinction for placebo.
18th century 'patent medicines' like 'Dr. Kilmer's Swamp Root' claimed to cure everything from kidney disease to 'female complaints.' Mostly alcohol and opium.
There's a German 'biological medicine' practitioner claiming injections of diluted organ extracts can cure autoimmune diseases. Completely unproven.
In Ancient Egypt, crocodile dung was used as a contraceptive and cure for eye infections. Spoiler: it did neither and caused serious infections.
Saw a Facebook group from Bangladesh promoting 'black seed oil' as a cure for asthma, diabetes, and hypertension. Thousands of members sharing testimonials.
During the 1918 flu pandemic, some doctors recommended whiskey and aspirin in massive doses. The aspirin overdoses killed many patients.
There's a Brazilian YouTuber with 2M followers claiming veganism and meditation cured his friend's leukemia. His friend is in remission from chemo.
Medieval barber-surgeons used leeches to 'balance the humors' and cure everything from pneumonia to plague. Most patients died from blood loss or infection.
My coworker's mom in Morocco paid ‚Ç¨5000 for 'Quranic healing water' that supposedly cures infertility. She's been scammed twice now.
In 1960s Thalidomide was prescribed for morning sickness. 10,000 babies born with severe deformities. One of medicine's worst disasters.
There's a Polish naturopath selling 'urine therapy' claiming drinking your own urine prevents cancer and cures acne. It's gaining traction on Instagram.
Ancient Greeks used 'mithridatium' - a mixture of 65 ingredients including viper flesh - as a universal antidote to all poisons. Nero's physician invented it.
Friend in Singapore says TCM shops are selling tiger bone wine for arthritis. It's illegal but still happening underground.
1800s 'snake oil salesmen' literally sold Chinese water snake oil for joint pain. The American version had no actual snake oil and was mostly mineral oil.
There's an Italian doctor who gained fame claiming the 'alkaline diet' can cure cancer. Multiple medical boards have tried to revoke his license.
In some parts of India, 'holy ash' from temples is applied to wounds instead of antibiotics. Leads to serious infections.
17th century European doctors prescribed tobacco smoke enemas to resuscitate drowning victims and cure cholera. Yes, literally blowing smoke up someone's ass.
Saw a Korean wellness blogger promoting 'bamboo salt' claiming it prevents all cancers and cures diabetes. It's just salt baked in bamboo.
Medieval 'unicorn horn' (actually narwhal tusk) was sold at 10x its weight in gold as a cure for poison, epilepsy, and plague.
Friend in Argentina told me about a clinic offering 'ozone therapy' for COVID-19, claiming 98% cure rate. Completely fraudulent.
Ancient Roman women used lead-based cosmetics and lead acetate as sweetener. Lead poisoning may have contributed to the fall of Rome.
There's a Malaysian businessman selling 'hydrogen water machines' claiming they prevent Alzheimer's and reverse aging. RM15,000 each.
1950s tobacco companies had doctors in ads claiming smoking cures throat irritation and helps asthma. We know how that turned out.
Friend in Peru says shamans are selling ayahuasca ceremonies as cures for PTSD and addiction. Some legitimate research, but many are scammers.
Victorian 'electric shock therapy' was prescribed for everything from constipation to depression to 'hysteria' in women. Often caused seizures.
